# A CONVERGENCE OF CONTINUOUS-TIME TEMPERED LANGEVIN DYNAMICS 

In this section, we give the proof of our continuous-time upper bound, Theorem 1. In Appendix A. 1 we discuss the well-posedness of the continuous time dynamics. The proof of Theorem 1 is then given in Appendix A.2. In the next section, Appendix A.3, we derive from Theorem 1 guarantees for convergence to a given precision. In Appendix A. 4 we give the proofs of the lemmas we used in the proof of Theorem 1.

## A. 1 WELL-POSEDNESS OF CONTINUOUS TEMPERED LANGEVIN DYNAMICS

Notice that in Equation (9), the drift $b(t, x)=\nabla \log \mu_{t}(x)$ is time-dependent and the diffusion coefficient is constant. Still, existence and uniqueness of solutions can be guaranteed under mild assumptions. For instance, if $\nabla \log \nu$ and $\nabla \log \pi$ are $L_{\nu}$ and $L_{\pi}$-Lipschitz respectively, the drift is also Lipschitz with bounded constant $L \leq \max \left(L_{\nu}, L_{\pi}\right)$ (since the dynamic $\lambda_{t}$ is bounded between 0 and 1 ), hence satisfy the usual linear growth condition in the second argument. In this case, there exists a unique, continuous strong solution $\left(X_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ adapted to the filtration generated by the Brownian motion which satisfies Equation (9) (Itô, 1951; Kotz et al., 2004). Strong uniqueness also means that if two processes satisfy this equation with the same initial conditions, their trajectories are almost surely indistinguishable. The law $\left(p_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ of Equation (9) satisfies a Fokker-Planck equation (Bogachev et al., 2022) that can be written

$$
\frac{\partial p_{t}}{\partial t}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot\left(p_{t} \nabla \log \left(\frac{p_{t}}{\mu_{t}}\right)\right)
$$

Generally, proving the existence and uniqueness of solutions for FPEs is more difficult than for SDEs, but one can also get under mild assumptions existence and uniqueness for solutions of Equation (18), under the same Lipschitzness assumptions on the score of proposal and target distributions, and using that the tempering dynamics are bounded in $[0,1]$ (Bris and Lions, 2008, Proposition 2).

## A. 2 Proof OF THEOREM 1

In this section, we will prove Theorem 1 on the convergence rate of tempered Langevin dynamics. The proof is in two steps: first, we compute how the process $p_{t}$ tracks the moving target $\mu_{t}$, then we compute how well the moving target $\mu_{t}$ tracks the final target $\pi$.

Step 1: contraction of $\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right)$ over time. Using the chain rule, we have

$$
\frac{d}{d t} \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right)=\int \log \left(\frac{p_{t}}{\mu_{t}}\right) \frac{\partial p_{t}}{\partial t}+\int \frac{-p_{t}}{\mu_{t}} \frac{\partial \mu_{t}}{\partial t}:=a+b
$$

The first term $a$ involves the Langevin dynamics given by the Fokker-Planck equation Eq. 18. Hence, using integration by parts and the inverse log-Sobolev constants defined in Eq. 8, we obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
a=\int \log \left(\frac{p_{t}}{\mu_{t}}\right) \nabla \cdot\left(p_{t} \nabla \log \left(\frac{p_{t}}{\mu_{t}}\right)\right) & =-\int p_{t}\left\|\nabla \log \left(\frac{p_{t}}{\mu_{t}}\right)\right\|^{2} \\
& =-\mathrm{FD}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right) \leq-2 \alpha_{t} \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The second term $b$ is specific to the tempering scheme: it involves the tempering dynamics $\dot{\mu}_{t}$, which is zero when there is no tempering and are here determined by the tempering rule $\mu_{t}=c_{\lambda_{t}} \nu^{1-\lambda_{t}} \pi^{\lambda_{t}}$, where $c_{\lambda_{t}}=1 / \int \nu^{1-\lambda_{t}} \pi^{\lambda_{t}}$ is a normalizing factor, that we will denote $c_{t}$ in this proof to alleviate notation. We can compute the (log) tempering dynamics

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial \log \mu_{t}}{\partial t} & =\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\lambda_{t} \log \frac{\pi}{\nu}+\log \nu-\log \int \nu^{1-\lambda_{t}} \pi^{\lambda_{t}}\right)=\dot{\lambda}_{t} \log \frac{\pi}{\nu}-\frac{\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \int \nu^{1-\lambda_{t}} \pi^{\lambda_{t}}}{\int \nu^{1-\lambda_{t}} \pi^{\lambda_{t}}} \\
& =\dot{\lambda}_{t} \log \frac{\pi}{\nu}-\dot{\lambda}_{t} \int \log \frac{\pi}{\nu} \frac{\nu^{1-\lambda_{t}} \pi^{\lambda_{t}}}{\int \nu^{1-\lambda_{t}} \pi^{\lambda_{t}}}=\dot{\lambda}_{t}\left(\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}-\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

so that the second term becomes

$$
b=\int p_{t} \frac{-\partial \log \mu_{t}}{\partial t}=\dot{\lambda}_{t}\left(\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]\right)
$$

To control this term we prove the following Lemma in Appendix A.4.

Lemma 10 (Discrepancy between the laws of the sampling process and tempering path) We have

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right] \leq 2\left(L_{\pi}+L_{\nu}\right)\left(\frac{2\left(d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}\right)}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}+\mathbb{E}_{p_{0}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]\right)
$$

Let $A$ be the right-hand side in Lemma 10, namely

$$
A:=2\left(L_{\pi}+L_{\nu}\right)\left(\frac{2\left(d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}\right)}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}+\mathbb{E}_{p_{0}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]\right)
$$

Then we obtain

$$
b \leq A \bar{\lambda}_{t}
$$

Combining Eq. 19 and Eq. 21 we obtain

$$
\frac{d}{d t} \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right) \leq-2 \alpha_{t} \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right)+A \bar{\lambda}_{t}
$$

To conclude this step, we apply Grönwall's lemma (Mischler, 2019, Lemma 1.1) to yield

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right) \leq \exp \left(\int_{0}^{t}-2 \alpha_{s} d s\right) \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{0}, \mu_{0}\right)+A \int_{0}^{t} \bar{\lambda}_{s} \exp \left(\int_{s}^{t}-2 \alpha_{v} d v\right) d s
$$

Step 2: compare $\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right)$ and $\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \pi\right)$. This measures how well the moving target $\mu_{t}$ tracks the final target $\pi$. We write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \pi\right) & =\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right)+\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \pi\right)-\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right) \\
& =\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right)+\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\mu_{t}}{\pi}\right] \\
& =\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right)+\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) \mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \left(\frac{\nu}{\pi}\right)\right]+\log c_{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

We make the following observation on the log normalizing constants, proved in Appendix A.4.
Lemma 11 (Bounding the normalizing constant of the law of the tempering path) We have

$$
0 \leq \log c_{t} \leq \min \left(\lambda_{t} \mathrm{KL}(\nu, \pi),\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) \mathrm{KL}(\pi, \nu)\right)
$$

Using Lemma 11 to control the normalizing constant $c_{t}$, we obtain

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \pi\right) \leq \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right)+\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right)\left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \left(\frac{\nu}{\pi}\right)\right]+\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\log \left(\frac{\pi}{\nu}\right)\right]\right)
$$

Finally, we control this last term using similar estimates as in Lemma 10; the proof is again deferred to Appendix A.4.
Lemma 12 (Discrepancy between the laws of the sampling process and target) We have

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right] \leq 2\left(L_{\pi}+L_{\nu}\right)\left(\frac{2\left(d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}\right)}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}+\mathbb{E}_{p_{0}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]\right)
$$

Applying this result we obtain

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \pi\right) \leq \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \mu_{t}\right)+\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) A
$$

Step 3: putting it together. We find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \pi\right) & \leq\left(u_{1}\right)+\left(u_{2}\right)+\left(u_{3}\right) \\
\left(u_{1}\right) & =\exp \left(-2 \int_{0}^{t} \alpha_{s} d s\right) \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{0}, \mu_{0}\right) \\
\left(u_{2}\right) & =\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) A \\
\left(u_{3}\right) & =A \int_{0}^{t} \bar{\lambda}_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{v} d v\right) d s
\end{aligned}
$$

# A. 3 CONTINUOUS-TIME CONVERGENCE IN PRECISION FORM 

As in Vempala and Wibisono (2019), we can derive from Theorem 1 sufficient conditions for convergence to precision $\epsilon$ by setting each of the three terms in the upper-bound to be less than $\epsilon / 3$.
Corollary 13 Suppose the assumptions of Theorem 1 hold. To achieve convergence with precision $\epsilon>0$ such that $\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \pi\right)<\epsilon$, sufficient conditions on the time $t$ and schedule $\lambda(\cdot)$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
t & >\max \left(\frac{1}{2 \alpha_{\min }} \log \left(\frac{3 \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{0}, \mu_{0}\right)}{\epsilon}\right), \frac{1}{\alpha_{\min }} \log \left(\frac{6 A}{\epsilon}\right)\right) \\
\lambda_{t} & >1-\frac{\epsilon}{3 A} \\
\lambda_{t} & <\frac{\epsilon}{6}+\lambda_{t / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\alpha_{\min }=\min _{s>0} \alpha_{s}$ is the smallest log-Sobolev constant among the path of tempered distributions.

Proof of Corollary 13. We upper-bound the first term by $\left(u_{1}\right) \leq e^{-2 t \alpha_{\min }} \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{0}, \mu_{0}\right)$ so that a sufficient condition for $\left(u_{1}\right)<\epsilon / 3$ is $t>\frac{1}{2 \alpha_{\min }} \log \left(\frac{3 \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{0}, p_{0}\right)}{\epsilon}\right)$.

A sufficient condition $\left(u_{2}\right)<\epsilon / 3$ is $\lambda_{t} \in] 1-\frac{\epsilon}{3 A}, 1]$. If $\lambda$ is bijective, this yields $t>\lambda^{-1}\left(1-\frac{\epsilon}{3 A}\right)$.
Finally, we upper-bound the third term:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(u_{3}\right) & =A \int_{0}^{t} \dot{\lambda}_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{\nu} d v\right) d s \\
& =A\left(\int_{0}^{t / 2} \dot{\lambda}_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{\nu} d v\right) d s+\int_{t / 2}^{t} \dot{\lambda}_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{\nu} d v\right) d s\right) \\
& \leq A\left(\exp \left(-2 \int_{t / 2}^{t} \alpha_{\nu} d v\right) \int_{0}^{t / 2} \dot{\lambda}_{s}+\int_{t / 2}^{t} \dot{\lambda}_{s} d s\right) \\
& \leq A\left(\exp \left(-t \alpha_{\min }\right)\left(\lambda_{t / 2}-\lambda_{0}\right)+\left(\lambda_{t}-\lambda_{t / 2}\right)\right) \\
& \leq A\left(\exp \left(-t \alpha_{\min }\right)+\left(\lambda_{t}-\lambda_{t / 2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

so that sufficient conditions for $\left(u_{3}\right)<\frac{\epsilon}{3}$ can be obtained by setting each of the two terms smaller than $\frac{\epsilon}{6}$, yielding $t>\frac{1}{\alpha_{\min }} \log \frac{6 A}{\epsilon}$ and $\lambda_{t}-\lambda_{t / 2}<\epsilon / 6$.

## A. 4 Proofs of TECHNical Lemmas From APPENDix A. 2

In this section, we give the deferred proofs from Appendix A.2. We first state and prove two observations that will be useful, before turning to the deferred proofs. The following proposition translates the dissipativity assumptions into a condition on the tails of the proposal and target.
Proposition 14 (Tails of the proposal and target) For all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, we have

$$
V_{\nu}(x)-\inf _{y \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} V_{\nu}(y) \leq 2 L_{\nu}\left(\|x\|^{2}+\frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}\right), \quad V_{\pi}(x)-\inf _{y \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} V_{\pi}(y) \leq 2 L_{\pi}\left(\|x\|^{2}+\frac{b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}}\right)
$$

Proof of Proposition 14. Observe that because

$$
\left\langle\nabla V_{\nu}(x), x\right\rangle \geq a_{\nu}\|x\|^{2}-b_{\nu}
$$

the function $V_{\nu}$ must be minimized by some point $x_{0} \in B\left(0, \sqrt{\frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}}\right)$. Therefore, for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$,

$$
V_{\nu}(x)-\inf _{y \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} V_{\nu}(y)=V_{\nu}(x)-V_{\nu}\left(x_{0}\right) \leq L_{\nu}\left\|x-x_{0}\right\|^{2} \leq 2 L_{\nu}\left(\|x\|^{2}+\frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}\right)
$$

The proof for $V_{\pi}$ is identical, so we omit it.

The next observation is our main quantitative use of the dissipativity assumption, and crucial for our control on the terms arising from the tempering dynamics in the continuous time convergence proof.
Lemma 15 (Bounded second moment along the dynamics) For all $t \geq 0$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right] \leq \max \left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{0}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right], \frac{d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}\right)
$$

Proof of Lemma 15. Using the Fokker-Planck equation Eq. 18 and integration by parts several times, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{t} \mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right] & =\int\|x\|^{2} \nabla \cdot\left(p_{t} \nabla \log \frac{p_{t}}{\mu_{t}}\right) \\
& =-2 \int\left\langle x, \nabla \log p_{t}-\nabla \log \mu_{t}\right\rangle p_{t} \\
& =2 d-2 \int\left\langle x,\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) \nabla V_{\nu}+\lambda_{t} \nabla V_{\pi}\right\rangle p_{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying the dissipativity assumption, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{t} \mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right] \leq 2\left(d+\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) b_{\nu}+\lambda_{t} b_{\pi}\right)-2\left(\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) a_{\nu}+\lambda_{t} a_{\pi}\right) \mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right] \\
\leq 2\left(d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}\right)-2\left(a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}\right) \mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, as soon as $\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]$ exceeds the level $\left(d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}\right) /\left(a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}\right)$, it must start decreasing. The result follows.

We now give the proofs of the Lemmas from Appendix A.2.
Proof of Lemma 10. Use Proposition 14 to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right] & =\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[V_{\nu}-V_{\pi}\right]+\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[V_{\pi}-V_{\nu}\right] \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[V_{\nu}-\inf _{y \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} V_{\nu}(y)\right]+\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[V_{\pi}-\inf _{y \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} V_{\pi}(y)\right] \\
& \leq 2 L_{\nu} \mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]+2 L_{\pi} \mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]+2 L_{\nu} \frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}+2 L_{\pi} \frac{b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $M$ be the quantity appearing on the right-hand side of Lemma 15. Then we obtain

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right] \leq 2 L_{\nu} \mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]+2 L_{\pi}\left(M+\frac{b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}}\right)+2 L_{\nu} \frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}
$$

To handle $\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]$, we apply the dissipativity assumption to yield

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right] \leq \frac{1}{\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) a_{\nu}+\lambda_{t} a_{\pi}} \mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\left\langle\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) \nabla V_{\nu}+\lambda_{t} V_{\pi}, x\right\rangle+\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) b_{\nu}+\lambda_{t} b_{\pi}\right]
$$

Integration by parts gives

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right] \leq \frac{d+\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) b_{\nu}+\lambda_{t} b_{\pi}}{\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) a_{\nu}+\lambda_{t} a_{\pi}} \leq \frac{d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}
$$

Hence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right] \leq & 2 L_{\pi}\left(\frac{b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}}+\max \left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{0}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right], \frac{d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}\right)\right) \\
& +2 L_{\nu}\left(\frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}+\frac{d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using $\max (x, y) \leq x+y$ when $x, y \geq 0$ and

$$
\frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}, \frac{b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}} \leq \frac{d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}
$$

we conclude.

Proof of Lemma 11. We have

$$
\log c_{t}=\log \left(\frac{1}{\int \nu^{1-\lambda_{t}} \pi^{\lambda_{t}}}\right)=-\log \int \nu^{1-\lambda_{t}} \pi^{\lambda_{t}}
$$

The lower bound is immediate from Hölder's inequality. For the upper bound, write

$$
\log c_{t}=-\log \mathbb{E}_{\nu}\left[\left(\frac{\pi}{\nu}\right)^{\lambda_{t}}\right] \leq \lambda_{t} \mathbb{E}_{\nu}\left[\log \frac{\nu}{\pi}\right]=\lambda_{t} \mathrm{KL}(\nu, \pi)
$$

using Jensen's inequality. Similarly, we can write

$$
\log c_{t}=-\log \mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\left(\frac{\nu}{\pi}\right)^{1-\lambda_{t}}\right] \leq\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) \mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]=\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) \mathrm{KL}(\pi, \nu)
$$

and therefore conclude that

$$
\log c_{t} \leq \min \left(\lambda_{t} \mathrm{KL}(\nu, \pi),\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) \mathrm{KL}(\pi, \nu)\right)
$$

Proof of Lemma 12. Denoting by $V_{\pi}^{*}$ (resp. $V_{\nu}^{*}$ ) the infimum of $V_{\pi}$ (resp. $V_{\nu}$ ), we have

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]=\int p_{t}\left(V_{\pi}-V_{\pi}^{*}-\left(V_{\nu}-V_{\nu}^{*}\right)\right)+\int d \pi\left(V_{\nu}-V_{\nu}^{*}\right)-\left(V_{\pi}-V_{\pi}^{*}\right)
$$

Using Proposition 14, we obtain the upper-bound

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right] \leq 2 L_{\pi}\left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]+\frac{b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}}\right)+2 L_{\nu}\left(\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]+\frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}\right)
$$

Let $M$ be the quantity appearing on the right-hand side of Lemma 15. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right] \leq 2 L_{\pi}\left(M+\frac{b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}}\right)+2 L_{\nu}\left(\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]+\frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}\right)
$$

On the other hand, a direct application of the dissipativity condition Assumption 2 implies

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right] \leq \frac{1}{a_{\pi}} \mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\left\langle x, \nabla V_{\pi}(x)\right\rangle+b_{\pi}\right]=\frac{d+b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}} \leq \frac{d+b_{\pi}+b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}
$$

Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right] & \leq 2 L_{\pi}\left(\max \left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{0}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right], \frac{d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}\right)+\frac{b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}}\right. \\
& \left.+2 L_{\nu} \frac{d+b_{\pi}+b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}+2 L_{\nu} \frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Again, bounding $\max (x, y) \leq x+y$ for $x, y \geq 0$ and using

$$
\frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}} ; \frac{b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}} \leq \frac{d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}
$$

we conclude.

# B CONVERGENCE OF DISCRETE-TIME TEMPERED LANGEVIN DYNAMICS 

In this section we give proof of our discrete-time upper bound, Theorem 3. In Appendix B. 1 we outline the proof of Theorem 3. In Appendix B.2, we derive from Theorem 3 sufficient conditions to precision $\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \pi\right)<\epsilon$. And in Appendix B. 3 we give the deferred proof from Appendix B.1.

## B. 1 Proof of Theorem 3

We next prove Theorem 3. Broadly speaking, the proof is in two steps: first, we compute how the process $p_{k}$ tracks the moving target $\mu_{k}$, then we compute how well the moving target $\mu_{k}$ tracks the final target $\pi$.

Step 1: contraction of $\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \mu_{k}\right)$. Using Vempala and Wibisono (2019, Lemma 3), under Assumptions 1 and 2 and $h_{k} \leq \frac{\alpha_{k}}{4 L_{k}^{k}}$, we obtain

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \mu_{k}\right) \leq \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k-1}, \mu_{k}\right) e^{-\alpha_{k} h_{k}}+6 h_{k}^{2} d L_{k}^{2}
$$

Next, we can compute the (log) tempering dynamics of $\mu_{k}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log \mu_{k-1}-\log \mu_{k} & =\left(\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{k-1}\right) \log \frac{\nu}{\pi}-\log \frac{\int \nu^{1-\lambda_{k-1}} \pi^{\lambda_{k-1}}}{\int \nu^{1-\lambda_{k}} \pi^{\lambda_{k}}} \\
& =\left(\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{k-1}\right) \log \frac{\nu}{\pi}-\log \int \frac{\nu^{1-\lambda_{k-1}} \pi^{\lambda_{k-1}}}{\nu^{1-\lambda_{k}} \pi^{\lambda_{k}}} \frac{\nu^{1-\lambda_{k}} \pi^{\lambda_{k}}}{\int \nu^{1-\lambda_{k}} \pi^{\lambda_{k}}} \\
& =\left(\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{k-1}\right) \log \frac{\nu}{\pi}-\log \mathbb{E}_{\mu_{k}}\left[\left(\frac{\nu}{\pi}\right)^{\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{k-1}}\right] \\
& \leq\left(\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{k-1}\right)\left(\log \frac{\nu}{\pi}-\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{k}}\left[\log \frac{\nu}{\pi}\right]\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used Jensen's inequality at the last step. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k-1}, \mu_{k}\right)= & \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k-1}, \mu_{k-1}\right)+\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k-1}, \mu_{k}\right)-\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k-1}, \mu_{k-1}\right) \\
= & \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k-1}, \mu_{k-1}\right)+\int p_{k-1} \log \frac{\mu_{k-1}}{\mu_{k}} \\
\leq & \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k-1}, \mu_{k-1}\right)+\left(\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{k-1}\right)\left(\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{k}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{k-1}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using Proposition 14 we can upper bound the difference of expectations via

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{k}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right]-\mathbb{E}_{p_{k-1}}\left[\log \frac{\pi}{\nu}\right] \leq 2 L_{\nu}\left(\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{k}}[\|x\|^{2}]+\frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}\right)+2 L_{\pi}\left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{k-1}}[\|x\|^{2}]+\frac{b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}}\right)
$$

The next Lemma, proved in Appendix B. 3 controls the second moment of $p_{k}$.
Lemma 16 (Bounded second moment along the dynamics) Suppose $h_{k} \leq \min \left(1, \frac{a_{\pi} \wedge a_{\nu}}{2\left(L_{\pi}+L_{\nu}\right)^{2}}\right)$. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}_{p_{k}}[\|x\|^{2}] \leq \max \left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{0}}[\|x\|^{2}], \frac{2\left(3\left(b_{\pi}+b_{\nu}\right) / 2+d\right)}{a_{\pi} \wedge a_{\mu} \wedge 1}\right)
$$

For the second moment of $\mu_{k}$ we use the following bound from the proof of Lemma 10

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mu_{k}}[\|x\|^{2}] \leq \frac{d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}
$$

To combine these bounds, let us define

$$
A^{\prime}:=2\left(L_{\pi}+L_{\nu}\right)\left\{\max \left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{0}}[\|x\|^{2}], \frac{2\left(3\left(b_{\pi}+b_{\nu}\right) / 2+d\right)}{a_{\pi} \wedge a_{\nu} \wedge 1}\right)+\frac{3\left(d+b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}\right)}{a_{\pi} \wedge a_{\nu}}\right\}
$$

Plugging into Eq. 31, we obtain

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \mu_{k}\right) \leq \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k-1}, \mu_{k-1}\right) e^{-\alpha_{k} h_{k}}+\left(\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{k-1}\right) A^{\prime} e^{-\alpha_{k} h_{k}}+6 h_{k}^{2} d L_{k}^{2}
$$

Now put $\psi_{i}^{k}:=\sum_{j=i}^{k} \alpha_{j} h_{j}$. Unrolling the recursion, we obtain

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \mu_{k}\right) \leq e^{-\psi_{1}^{k}} \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{0}, \mu_{0}\right)+\sum_{i=1}^{k}\left(A^{\prime}\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i-1}\right) e^{-\alpha_{i} h_{i}}+6 h_{i}^{2} d L_{i}^{2}\right) e^{-\psi_{i+1}^{k}}
$$

Step 2: compare $\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \mu_{k}\right)$ and $\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \pi\right)$. Here we use Lemma 11 to control the lognormalizing constants and obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \pi\right) & =\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \mu_{k}\right)+\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \pi\right)-\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \mu_{k}\right) \\
& =\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \mu_{k}\right)+\mathbb{E}_{p_{k}}\left[\log \frac{\mu_{k}}{\pi}\right] \\
& =\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \mu_{k}\right)+\left(1-\lambda_{k}\right) \mathbb{E}_{p_{k}}\left[\log \frac{\nu}{\pi}\right]+\log c_{k} \\
& \leq \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \mu_{k}\right)+\left(1-\lambda_{k}\right)\left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{k}}\left[\log \frac{\nu}{\pi}\right]+\mathrm{KL}(\pi, \nu)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

To control the term in parentheses, we apply Proposition 14 to yield

$$
\mathbb{E}_{p_{k}}\left[\log \frac{\nu}{\pi}\right]+\operatorname{KL}(\pi, \nu) \leq 2 L_{\pi}\left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{k}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]+\frac{b_{\pi}}{a_{\pi}}\right)+2 L_{\nu}\left(\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]+\frac{b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu}}\right)
$$

Using Lemma 15 and the following bound from the proof of Lemma 12

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right] \leq \frac{d+b_{\pi}+b_{\nu}}{a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}}
$$

we find

$$
\mathbb{E}_{p_{k}}\left[\log \frac{\nu}{\pi}\right]+\operatorname{KL}(\pi, \nu) \leq A^{\prime}
$$

for $A^{\prime}$ as in Eq. 32.
Step 3: putting it together. Combining the results of steps 1 and 2, we can finally write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \pi\right) & \leq\left(v_{1}\right)+\left(v_{2}\right)+\left(v_{3}\right)+\left(v_{4}\right) \\
\left(v_{1}\right) & =\exp \left(-\sum_{j=1}^{k} \alpha_{j} h_{j}\right) \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{0}, \mu_{1}\right) \\
\left(v_{2}\right) & =\left(1-\lambda_{k}\right) A^{\prime} \\
\left(v_{3}\right) & =A^{\prime} \sum_{i=1}^{k}\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i-1}\right) \exp \left(-\sum_{j=i}^{k} \alpha_{j} h_{j}\right) \\
\left(v_{4}\right) & =6 \sum_{i=1}^{k} h_{k}^{2} d L_{k}^{2} \exp \left(-\sum_{j=i+1}^{k} \alpha_{j} h_{j}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

# B. 2 DISCRETE-TIME CONVERGENCE IN PRECISION FORM 

Corollary 17 To achieve convergence with precision $\epsilon>0$ such that $\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \pi\right)<\epsilon$, sufficient conditions are

$$
\begin{aligned}
h & <\min \left(\frac{1}{4 \alpha_{\min}}, \frac{\alpha_{\min }}{96 L_{\max }^{2} d} \epsilon, \frac{\alpha_{\min }}{4\left(L_{\pi}+L_{\nu}\right)^{2}}, \frac{a_{\pi} \wedge a_{\nu}}{2\left(L_{\pi}+L_{\nu}\right)^{2}}, 1\right) \\
k & >\max \left(\frac{1}{h \alpha_{\min }} \log \left(\frac{4 \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{0}, \mu_{1}\right)}{\epsilon}\right), \frac{2}{h \alpha_{\min }} \log \left(\frac{8 A^{\prime}}{\epsilon}\right)\right) \\
\lambda_{k} & >1-\frac{\epsilon}{4 A^{\prime}} \\
\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{\lfloor k / 2\rfloor} & <\frac{\epsilon}{24 A^{\prime}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\alpha_{\min }=\min _{\epsilon>0} \alpha_{s}$ and $L_{\max }=\max _{\epsilon>0} L_{s}$ denote the smallest (resp. largest) log-Sobolev (resp. smoothness) constant among the path of tempered distributions.

Proof of Corollary 17. Again, as in Vempala and Wibisono (2019), we can derive sufficient conditions for convergence with a given precision $\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{k}, \pi\right)<\epsilon$ by setting each of the four terms in the upper-bound inferior to $\epsilon / 4$.
First, we upper-bound the fourth term:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(v_{4}\right) & \leq 6 h^{2} d L_{\max }^{2} \sum_{i=1}^{k} e^{-(k-i) h \alpha_{\min }}=6 h^{2} d L_{\max }^{2} \frac{1-e^{-k h \alpha_{\min }}}{1-e^{-h \alpha_{\min }}} \\
& \leq 6 h^{2} d L_{\max }^{2} \frac{1}{1-e^{-h \alpha_{\min }}} \leq 6 h^{2} d L_{\max }^{2} \frac{4}{3 h \alpha_{\min }}=\frac{8 h d L_{\max }^{2}}{\alpha_{\min }}
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the last inequality, similarly to Vempala and Wibisono (2019), we use that $1-e^{-c} \geq \frac{3}{4} c$ for $0<c=h \alpha_{\min } \leq \frac{1}{4}$ which holds assuming that $h \leq \frac{1}{4 \alpha_{\min }}$. Thus, a sufficient condition for $\left(v_{4}\right) \leq \epsilon / 4$ is $h \leq \frac{\alpha_{\min }}{32 L_{\max }^{2} d} \epsilon$.

Next, we upper-bound the first term by $\left(v_{1}\right) \leq e^{-k h \alpha_{\min }} \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{0}, \mu_{0}\right)$ so that a sufficient condition for $\left(v_{1}\right)<\epsilon / 4$ is $k>\frac{1}{h \alpha_{\min }} \log \left(\frac{4 \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{0}, \mu_{0}\right)}{\epsilon}\right)$.
A sufficient condition $\left(v_{2}\right)<\epsilon / 4$ is $\left.\lambda_{k} \in\right] 1-\frac{\epsilon}{4 A^{\prime}}, 1]$.
Finally, we upper-bound the third term:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(v_{3}\right) & :=A^{\prime} \sum_{i=1}^{k}\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i-1}\right) \exp \left(-h \sum_{j=i}^{k} \alpha_{j}\right) \\
& =A^{\prime}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor k / 2\rfloor}\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i-1}\right) \exp \left(-h \sum_{j=i}^{k} \alpha_{j}\right)+\sum_{i=\lfloor k / 2\rfloor}^{k}\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i-1}\right) \exp \left(-h \sum_{j=i}^{k} \alpha_{j}\right)\right) \\
& \leq A^{\prime}\left(\exp \left(-h \sum_{j=\lfloor k / 2\rfloor}^{k} \alpha_{j}\right) \sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor k / 2\rfloor}\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i-1}\right)+\sum_{i=\lfloor k / 2\rfloor}^{k}\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i-1}\right)\right) \\
& \leq A^{\prime}\left(\exp \left(-h k \alpha_{\min } / 2\right)\left(\lambda_{\lfloor k / 2\rfloor}-\lambda_{1}\right)+\left(\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{\lfloor k / 2\rfloor}\right)\right) \\
& \leq A^{\prime} \exp \left(-h k \alpha_{\min } / 2\right)+A^{\prime}\left(\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{\lfloor k / 2\rfloor}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

so that sufficient conditions for $\left(v_{3}\right)<\frac{\epsilon}{4}$ can be obtained by setting each of the two terms smaller than $\frac{\epsilon}{8}$, yielding $k>\frac{2}{\alpha_{\min } h} \log \frac{8 A^{\prime}}{\epsilon}$ and $\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{\lfloor k / 2\rfloor}<\frac{\epsilon}{8 A^{\prime}}$.

# B. 3 TECHNICAL LEMMA FROM APPENDIX B. 1 

In this section, we prove Lemma 16.

Proof of Lemma 16. We recall that the particles follow the recursion

$$
X_{k+1}=X_{k}-h_{k} \nabla V_{\lambda_{k}}\left(X_{k}\right)+\sqrt{2 h_{k}} z_{k}
$$

where $z_{k}$ follows a standard normal distribution on $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $X_{k} \sim p_{k}$. Hence, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k+1}\right\|^{2}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}-h_{k} \nabla V_{\lambda_{k}}\left(X_{k}\right)+\sqrt{2 h_{k}} z_{k}\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}-h_{k} \nabla V_{\lambda_{k}}\left(X_{k}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+2 d h_{k} \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right]-2 h_{k} \mathbb{E}\left[X_{k}^{\top} \nabla V_{\lambda_{k}}\left(X_{k}\right)\right]+h_{k}^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla V_{\lambda_{k}}\left(X_{k}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+2 d h_{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

The dissipativity assumption yields $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{k}^{\top} \nabla V_{\lambda_{k}}\left(X_{k}\right)\right] \geq\left(a_{\pi} \wedge a_{\nu}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right]-\left(b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}\right)$ and as in the proof of Proposition 14 we have $\left\|\nabla V_{\lambda_{k}}\left(X_{k}\right)\right\|^{2} \leq 2\left(L_{\pi}+L_{\nu}\right)^{2}\left(\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}+\frac{b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}}{a_{\mu} \wedge a_{\pi}}\right)$ so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k+1}\right\|^{2}\right] \leq & \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right]-2 h_{k}\left(\left(a_{\pi} \wedge a_{\nu}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right]-\left(b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}\right)\right)+2 d h_{k} \\
& +2 h_{k}^{2}\left(L_{\pi}+L_{\nu}\right)^{2}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}}{a_{\mu} \wedge a_{\pi}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Letting $L:=L_{\pi}+L_{\nu}, a:=a_{\nu} \wedge a_{\pi}$ and $b:=b_{\nu}+b_{\pi}$ we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k+1}\right\|^{2}\right] & \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right]-2 h_{k}\left(\left(a-h_{k} L^{2}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right]-(b+d)-h_{k} \frac{L b}{a}\right) \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right]\left(1-2 h_{k}\left(a-h_{k} L^{2}\right)\right)+2 h_{k}\left(b+d+h_{k} \frac{L^{2} b}{a}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now by induction, assume that $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right] \leq \max \left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{0}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right]\right), \frac{2(3 b / 2+d)}{a \wedge 1}$ ). By construction on $h_{k}$, $a-h_{k} L^{2}>0$ hence if $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right]>\frac{b+d+h_{k} L^{2} b / a}{2 h_{k}\left(a-h_{k} L^{2}\right)}$, then $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k+1}\right\|^{2}\right]<\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right]$ and in particular $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k+1}\right\|^{2}\right] \leq \max \left(\mathbb{E}_{p_{0}}\left[\|x\|^{2}\right], \frac{2(3 b / 2+d)}{a \wedge 1}\right)$. Now, if $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k}\right\|^{2}\right] \leq \frac{b+d+h_{k} L^{2} b / a}{2 h_{k}\left(a-h_{k} L^{2}\right)}$, then if

$1>2 h_{k}\left(a-h_{k} L^{2}\right)$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k+1}\right\|^{2}\right] & \leq \frac{b+d+h_{k} L^{2} b / a}{a-h_{k} L^{2}}\left(1-2 h_{k}\left(a-h_{k} L^{2}\right)\right)+2 h_{k}\left(b+d+h_{k} L^{2} b / a\right) \\
& =\frac{b+d+h_{k} L^{2} b / a}{a-h_{k} L^{2}} \\
& \leq \frac{2(3 b / 2+d)}{a}
\end{aligned}
$$

by construction on $h_{k}$. Conversely, if $1 \leq 2 h_{k}\left(a-h_{k} L^{2}\right)$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|X_{k+1}\right\|^{2}\right] & \leq 2 h_{k}\left(b+d+h_{k} \frac{L^{2} b}{a}\right) \\
& \leq 2(3 b / 2+d)
\end{aligned}
$$

# C OPTIMIZATION OF CONTINUOUS-TIME TEMPERED LANGEVIN DYNAMICS
## C. 1 Proof of Corollary 5

We will rewrite and bound the terms $\left(u_{1}\right),\left(u_{2}\right)$ and $\left(u_{3}\right)$ in the upper bound of Theorem 1 provided in Eq. 34, so that the role of the tempering schedule $\lambda(\cdot)$ is more explicit, at the expense of a looser upper-bound.

Rewriting $\left(u_{3}\right)$. We begin with the third term, using integration by parts to write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(u_{3}\right) & :=A \int_{0}^{t} \dot{\lambda}_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{v} d v\right) d s \\
& =A\left(\lambda_{t}-\lambda_{0} \exp \left(-2 \int_{0}^{t} \alpha_{v} d v\right)-2 \int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \alpha_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{v} d v\right) d s\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Recalling $\left(u_{2}\right)$. Recall that

$$
\left(u_{2}\right)=A\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right)
$$

Rewriting $\left(u_{1}\right)$. We recall that $\left(u_{1}\right)=\exp \left(-2 \int_{0}^{t} \alpha_{v} d v\right) \mathrm{KL}\left(p_{0}, \mu_{0}\right)$. Assuming that the process is initialized at the proposal distribution $p_{0}=\nu$, we can use the tempering rule $\mu_{t}=c_{t} \nu^{1-\lambda_{t}} \pi^{\lambda_{t}}$ to rewrite the KL term

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(\nu, \mu_{0}\right)=\lambda_{0} \mathrm{KL}(\nu, \pi)-\log c_{0}
$$

By positivity of $\log c_{0}$, we can write $-\log c_{0} \leq \lambda_{0} \mathrm{KL}(\pi, \nu)$. In particular

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{KL}\left(\nu, \mu_{0}\right) & \leq \lambda_{0}(\mathrm{KL}(\nu, \pi)+\mathrm{KL}(\pi, \nu)) \\
& =\lambda_{0}\left(\int\left[V_{\pi}(x)-V_{\pi}^{*}-\left(V_{\nu}(x)-V_{\nu}^{*}\right)\right] d \nu(x)+\int\left[V_{\nu}(x)-V_{\nu}^{*}-\left(V_{\pi}(x)-V_{\pi}^{*}\right)\right] d \pi(x)\right) \\
& \leq \lambda_{0} A
\end{aligned}
$$

Upper bounding the sum. We can now combine upper bounds on $\left(u_{1}\right),\left(u_{2}\right)$ and $\left(u_{3}\right)$ and simplify the result, using that the terms $\lambda_{0} A \exp \left(-2 \int_{0}^{t} \alpha_{v} d v\right)$ and $A \lambda_{t}$ cancel out, to finally yield

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(p_{t}, \pi\right) \leq A \cdot G_{t}(\lambda), \quad G_{t}(\lambda):=1-2 \int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \alpha_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{v} \mathrm{~d} v\right) \mathrm{d} s
$$

Optimal schedule when $\alpha_{\pi} \geq \alpha_{\nu} \quad$ Now, let $\Phi_{s}:=\exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{u} \mathrm{~d} u\right)$. We have

$$
G_{t}(\lambda)=1-2 \int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \alpha_{s} \Phi_{s} \mathrm{~d} s
$$

Applying integration by parts, we find

$$
G_{t}(\lambda)=1-\left[\lambda_{s} \Phi_{s}\right]_{0}^{t}+\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\lambda}_{s} \Phi_{s} \mathrm{~d} s=1-\lambda_{t}+\lambda_{0} \Phi_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\lambda}_{s} \Phi_{s} \mathrm{~d} s
$$

Since $\dot{\lambda}_{s} \geq 0$ and $\Phi_{s} \geq e^{-2(t-s) \alpha_{\pi}}$ (using the assumption $\alpha_{\pi} \geq \alpha_{\nu}$ ), it follows that

$$
G_{t}(\lambda) \geq 1-\lambda_{t}+\lambda_{0} e^{-2 t \alpha_{\pi}}+\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\lambda}_{s} e^{-2(t-s) \alpha_{\pi}} \mathrm{d} s
$$

Reversing the integration by parts, we obtain

$$
G_{t}(\lambda) \geq 1-2 \int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \alpha_{\pi} e^{-2(t-s) \alpha_{\pi}} \mathrm{d} s \geq 1-2 \int_{0}^{t} \alpha_{\pi} e^{-2(t-s) \alpha_{\pi}} \mathrm{d} s
$$

where the last inequality uses $\lambda_{s} \leq 1$. Recognizing the right-hand side as $G_{t}$ evaluated at schedule $\lambda \equiv 1$, we conclude.

# C. 2 Proof of Proposition 6 

Sketch of proof. We first make the change of variable $\Phi(s)=\exp \left(-\int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{u} d u\right)$ so that the problem can be re-written as

$$
\sup _{\Phi \in I_{t}} \frac{1}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\left(\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}-\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}_{s}^{2} d s-\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} \Phi_{0}^{2}\right)
$$

where $I_{t}$ is the set of strictly positive functions $\Phi:[0, t] \mapsto \mathbb{R}$ with weak second derivative and such that $\alpha_{\pi} \Phi \leq \dot{\Phi} \leq \alpha_{\nu} \Phi$ and $\Phi \ddot{\Phi} \leq \dot{\Phi}^{2}$ and $\Phi(t)=1$. Unlike the previous objective $G(\cdot)$, note that our new problem has now a concave objective yet has non-convex (and non closed) constraints. Hence we make a convex relaxation and solve instead

$$
\sup _{\Phi \in J_{t}} \frac{1}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\left(\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}-\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}_{s}^{2} d s-\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} \Phi_{0}^{2}\right)
$$

where $J_{t}$ is the set of non-negative functions in $W^{1,2}([0, t])$ such that $\alpha_{\pi} \Phi \leq \dot{\Phi}$ and $\Phi(t)=1$. After showing that an optimal solution $\Phi$ indeed exists, we explicitly describe it and show that it belongs to $I_{t}$ a.k.a. it verifies the original constraints. In order to come up with an explicit solution $\Phi$, we make a disjunction of cases on whether the constraint $\alpha_{\pi} \Phi \leq \dot{\Phi}$ is saturated: if it is always saturated, then $\Phi$ is exponential if not, then it must be linear on a maximal neighborhood around the non saturated point. We then prove that this maximal neighborhood is unique, pathwise connected and can only be of the form $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$ with $x_{0} \leq t$ so that $\Phi$ is linear on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$ and is then exponential on $\left[x_{0}, t\right]$.

Proof of Prop. 6. We first notice that minimizing $G_{t}$ defined in Corollary 5 over the set of admissible tempering schedules $\lambda$ is equivalent to solving

$$
\sup _{\lambda \in \Lambda_{t}} \int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \alpha_{\pi} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{u} \mathrm{~d} u\right) \mathrm{d} s
$$

where $\Lambda_{t}$ is the set of functions from $[0, t]$ to $[0,1]$ with non-negative weak derivative.
Proposition 18 Suppose $\alpha_{\pi}<\alpha_{\nu}$ and let $I_{t}$ be the set of positive functions $\Phi$ with weak second derivative, such that $\Phi_{t}=1, \alpha_{\pi} \Phi \leq \dot{\Phi} \leq \alpha_{\nu} \Phi$ and $\ddot{\Phi} \Phi-\dot{\Phi}^{2}$ is a non-positive measure. Then

$$
\sup _{\lambda \in \Lambda_{t}} \int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \alpha_{\pi} \exp \left(-2 \int \alpha_{u} \mathrm{~d} u\right) \mathrm{d} s=\sup _{\Phi \in I_{t}} \frac{1}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\left(\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}-\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}_{s}^{2} d s-\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} \Phi_{0}^{2}\right)
$$

Proof. Let $\lambda \in \Lambda_{t}$ and denote $\Phi_{s}:=\Phi(s)=\exp \left(-\int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{u} \mathrm{~d} u\right)$. The function $\Phi$ is strictly positive and such that $\Phi_{t}=1$. Its first and second derivatives read

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\dot{\Phi}_{s}=\alpha_{s} \Phi_{s} \\
\dot{\Phi}_{s}=\dot{\alpha}_{s} \Phi_{s}+\frac{\dot{\Phi}_{s}^{2}}{\Phi_{s}}
\end{array}\right.
$$

In particular, since $\lambda \in[0,1]$ and $\alpha_{s}=\left(1-\lambda_{s}\right) \alpha_{\nu}+\lambda_{s} \alpha_{\pi}$, we have $\alpha_{s} \in\left[\alpha_{\pi}, \alpha_{\nu}\right]$ and by positiveness of $\Phi$, it holds

$$
\alpha_{\pi} \Phi \leq \dot{\Phi} \leq \alpha_{\nu} \Phi
$$

Similarly, since $\dot{\lambda}$ is a non-negative measure, $\dot{\alpha}=\left(\alpha_{\pi}-\alpha_{\nu}\right) \dot{\lambda}$ is a non-positive measure and so is $\dot{\alpha} \Phi^{2}$. This implies in particular

$$
\ddot{\Phi} \Phi-\dot{\Phi}^{2}=\dot{\alpha} \Phi^{2} \leq 0
$$

Hence we verified that $\Phi \in I_{t}$. Furthermore, it reads

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \alpha_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{u} \mathrm{~d} u\right) \mathrm{d} s & =\frac{1}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}} \int_{0}^{t}\left(\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{s}\right) \alpha_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{u} \mathrm{~d} u\right) \mathrm{d} s \\
& =\frac{1}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}} \int_{0}^{t} \alpha_{\nu} \dot{\Phi}_{s} \Phi_{s}-\dot{\Phi}_{s}^{2} \mathrm{~d} s \\
& =\frac{1}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\left(\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}\left[\Phi_{s}^{2}\right]_{0}^{t}-\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}_{s}^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\left(\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}\left(1-\Phi_{0}^{2}\right)-\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}^{2}(s) \mathrm{d} s\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In particular, we have

$$
\sup _{\lambda \in \Lambda_{t}} \int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \alpha_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int \alpha_{u} d u\right) d s \leq \sup _{\Phi \in I_{t}} \frac{1}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\left(\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}-\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}_{s}^{2} d s-\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} \Phi_{0}^{2}\right)
$$

Conversely, let $\Phi \in I_{t}$, defining $\alpha_{s}=\partial_{s} \log \Phi=\dot{\Phi} / \Phi$ and $\lambda_{s}=\frac{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{s}}{\alpha_{s}-\alpha_{\nu}}$ we have by construction that $\lambda \in \Lambda_{t}$. Furthermore, the previous computations show that

$$
\frac{1}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\left(\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}\left(1-\Phi_{0}^{2}\right)-\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}_{s}^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)=\int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \alpha_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int \alpha_{u} \mathrm{~d} u\right) d s
$$

In particular, we recover the reverse inequality

$$
\sup _{\Phi \in I_{t}} \frac{1}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\left(\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}-\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}_{s}^{2} d s-\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} \Phi_{0}^{2}\right) \leq \sup _{\lambda \in \Lambda_{t}} \int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \alpha_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int \alpha_{u} \mathrm{~d} u\right) \mathrm{d} s
$$

Hence the problem can be re-written as the minimization of the convex functional $\Phi \mapsto \int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}_{s}^{2} d s+$ $\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} \Phi_{0}^{2}$ under the constraint $\Phi \in I_{t}$. As can be noted, the constraint $\ddot{\Phi} \Phi-\dot{\Phi}^{2} \leq 0$ is non-convex and the constraints $\Phi>0, \Phi$ has a weak second derivative are non-closed. Hence we are going to relax all of these constraints and solve instead

$$
\inf _{\Phi \in J_{t}} \int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}_{s}^{2} \mathrm{~d} s+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} \Phi_{0}^{2}
$$

where $J_{t} \subset W^{1,2}([0, t])$ is the set of positive functions such that $\Phi_{t}=1, \alpha_{\pi} \Phi \leq \dot{\Phi}$ almost everywhere. Note that we also dropped the constraint $\dot{\Phi} \leq \alpha_{\nu} \Phi$ for convenience of the proof. Nevertheless, we show that at the optimum, the solution of the problem above verifies all the initial constraints.
Proposition 19 Assume $\alpha_{\pi}<\alpha_{\nu}$. Then Eq. 54 admits a minimizer $\Phi$ which has the following expression:

1. If $\alpha_{\pi}>\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}$, then $\Phi_{s}=e^{\alpha_{\pi}(s-t)}$.

2. If $\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{t \alpha_{\nu}+2}<\alpha_{\pi} \leq \frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}$, then

$$
\Phi_{s}= \begin{cases}\alpha_{\pi} e^{\alpha_{\pi}\left(\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}-t\right)} s+\frac{2 \alpha_{\pi}}{\alpha_{\nu}} e^{\alpha_{\pi}\left(\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}-t\right)} & s \leq \frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}} \\ e^{\alpha_{\pi}(s-t)} & s>\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}\end{cases}
$$

3. If $\alpha_{\pi} \leq \frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{t \alpha_{\nu}+2}$, then $\Phi_{s}=\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2+t \alpha_{\nu}} s+\left(1-\frac{t \alpha_{\nu}}{2+t \alpha_{\nu}}\right)$.

Proof. We aim to solve the minimization problem defined in Eq. 54.
Existence of a minimum. Since the objective has compact sub-level sets and is continuous for the $W^{1,2}([0, t])$ norm, we can extract a minimizing sequence $\left(\Phi_{n}\right)_{n}$ in $J_{t}$ that converges in $W^{1,2}$ towards some $\Phi$ in $W^{1,2}([0, t])$. Because $W^{1,2}$ metrizes pointwise convergence, we obtain that the infimum verifies two of the constraints: $\Phi_{t}=1$ and $\Phi \geq 0$ almost everywhere.
Then, since $\Phi_{n} \in J_{t}$, for $s_{0}, h>0$ such that $s_{0}, s_{0}+h \in[0, t]$ we have $0 \leq \alpha_{\pi} \Phi_{n} \leq \dot{\Phi}_{n}$ and then:

$$
\alpha_{\pi}\left(\Phi_{n}\right)_{s_{0}} \leq \frac{\alpha_{\pi}}{h} \int_{s_{0}}^{s_{0}+h}\left(\Phi_{n}\right)_{s} \mathrm{~d} s \leq \frac{1}{h} \int_{s_{0}}^{s_{0}+h}\left(\dot{\Phi}_{n}\right)_{s} \mathrm{~d} s=\frac{\left(\Phi_{n}\right)_{s_{0}+h}-\left(\Phi_{n}\right)_{s_{0}}}{h}
$$

Letting $n$ go to infinity and $h$ to zero, we obtain, for almost all $s_{0} \in[0, t]$

$$
\alpha_{\pi} \Phi_{s_{0}} \leq \dot{\Phi}_{s_{0}}
$$

hence $\Phi \in J_{t}$, showing $\Phi$ is a minimizer of Eq. 54.
Explicit expression of the minimum. We now derive an explicit expression for $\Phi$ based on whether or not there exists a point $x_{0}$ where the constraint

$$
\alpha_{\pi} \Phi \leq \dot{\Phi}
$$

is not saturated.
Case 1: the inequality is saturated everywhere. In the case where the inequality constraint above is saturated for $x$ almost everywhere, we obtain that the minimizer $\Phi$ is of the form $\Phi_{s}=$ $K \exp \left(\alpha_{\pi} s\right)$ and using the fact that $\Phi_{t}=1$, we recover that $\Phi_{s}=\exp \left((s-t) \alpha_{\pi}\right)$.

Case 2: the inequality is not saturated saturated everywhere. Now let us assume that there exists $x_{0}$ where the inequality is not saturated by the minimizer

$$
\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}\right)<\dot{\Phi}\left(x_{0}\right)
$$

We can make a disjunction of cases with respect to $x_{0}$.
If $x_{0}=t$. We will show that $\Phi$ is linear on $[0, t]$. We first define a neighborhood of $x_{0}$ of size $\epsilon$ that satisfies a certain inequality. By continuity of $\Phi$ and the definition of the derivative, there exists an $\epsilon>0$ such that for all $\delta<\epsilon$

$$
\alpha_{\pi} \Phi(t)<\frac{\Phi(t)-\Phi(t-\delta)}{\delta}
$$

Let us now define the neighborhood size $\epsilon$ to be the largest $\epsilon>0$ such that $t-\epsilon \geq 0$ and such that the inequality above holds for all $\delta<\epsilon$.

Next, we define a candidate $\tilde{\Phi}$ that is linear in this neighborhood, and equal to the minimizer $\Phi$ outside the neighborhood. Let

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\tilde{\Phi}(x)=\Phi(x) \text { if } x \notin[t-\epsilon, t] \\
\tilde{\Phi}(x)=\frac{\Phi(t)-\Phi(t-\epsilon)}{\epsilon}(x-t+\epsilon)+\Phi(t-\epsilon) \text { if } x \in[t-\epsilon, t]
\end{array}\right.
$$

By construction, $\tilde{\Phi}$ verifies the constraints, i.e. $\tilde{\Phi} \in J_{t}$. Indeed, taking $\delta \rightarrow \epsilon$ in Eq. 55, and using the monotonicity of $\tilde{\Phi}$, we get successively for almost every $x \in[0, t]$ :

$$
\alpha_{\pi} \tilde{\Phi}(x) \leq \alpha_{\pi} \tilde{\Phi}(t) \leq \frac{\Phi(t)-\Phi(t-\epsilon)}{\epsilon}=\tilde{\Phi}(x)
$$

Hence, $\bar{\Phi}$ is a suitable candidate for solving Problem Eq. 54.
Finally, we show that the candidate we built $\bar{\Phi}$ achieves a smaller objective than a minimizer and must therefore be equal to a minimizer $\Phi \in J_{t}$. By optimality,

$$
\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}^{2}(s) d s+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} \Phi(0)^{2} \leq \int_{0}^{t} \dot{\bar{\Phi}}^{2}(s) d s+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} \dot{\Phi}(0)^{2}
$$

and since $\Phi$ and $\bar{\Phi}$ coincide on $[0, t-\epsilon]$, it holds

$$
\int_{t-\epsilon}^{t} \dot{\Phi}^{2}(s) d s \leq \frac{(\Phi(t)-\Phi(t-\epsilon))^{2}}{\epsilon}
$$

The same inequality in the other direction is obtained by applying Jensen's inequality

$$
\int_{t-\epsilon}^{t} \dot{\Phi}^{2}(s) d s \geq \epsilon\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon} \int_{t-\epsilon}^{t} \dot{\Phi}(s) d s\right)^{2}=\frac{(\Phi(t)-\Phi(t-\epsilon))^{2}}{\epsilon}
$$

We are therefore in the equality case of Jensen with a strongly convex and smooth function, so it must hold for $s$ almost everywhere in the neighborhood $[t-\epsilon, t]$ that

$$
\dot{\Phi}(s)=\frac{\Phi(t)-\Phi(t-\epsilon)}{\epsilon}
$$

and in particular $\Phi$ is linear in the neighborhood $[t-\epsilon, t]$ and is of the form $\Phi(x)=a x+b$.
Finally, we will show that the neighborhood covers the entire interval $[0, t]$, or in other words, that $\epsilon=t$. Suppose it is not the case and $\epsilon<t$. Then, by continuity of $\Phi$ at the neighborhood border $t-\epsilon$,

$$
\alpha_{\pi} \Phi(t)=\frac{\Phi(t)-\Phi(t-\epsilon)}{\epsilon}
$$

Combined with the fact that $\Phi(t)=1$, this implies $a=\alpha_{\pi}$ which is a contradiction with the inequality Eq. 55 that characterizes the neighborhood, and in particular yields $a>\alpha_{\pi}$. Hence, we must have $\epsilon=t$ and in particular, $\Phi$ is linear on the whole interval $[0, t]$.

If $x_{0} \in] 0, t\left[\right.$ As before we can define $\epsilon_{+}$and $\epsilon_{-}$as the largest $\epsilon>0$ such that $x_{0}+\epsilon<t$ (resp. $\left.x_{0}-\epsilon>0\right)$ and $\frac{\Phi\left(x_{0}+\delta\right)-\Phi\left(x_{0}\right)}{\delta}>\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}+\delta\right)$ for all $\delta<\epsilon_{+}$(resp. $\left.\frac{\Phi\left(x_{0}\right)-\Phi\left(x_{0}-\delta\right)}{2}>\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}\right)\right.$ for all $\delta<\epsilon_{-}$). Again, we obtain that $\Phi$ must be linear on $\left[x_{0}, x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}\right]$of the form $\Phi(x)=a_{+} x+b_{+}$ and linear on $\left[x_{0}-\epsilon_{-}, x_{0}\right]$ of the form $\Phi(x)=a_{-} x+b_{-}$. Furthermore, since $\Phi$ is differentiable at $x_{0}$, its derivative must read

$$
\dot{\Phi}\left(x_{0}\right)=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{\Phi\left(x_{0}+h\right)-\Phi\left(x_{0}\right)}{h}=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{\Phi\left(x_{0}\right)-\Phi\left(x_{0}-h\right)}{h}
$$

which implies $a_{+}=a_{-}:=a$ and by continuity of $\Phi$ at $x_{0}$, we also recover $b_{+}=b_{-}$. In particular, $\Phi$ is linear across the whole interval $\left[x_{0}-\epsilon_{-}, x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}\right]$. We have now four possibilities: either a) $x_{0}-\epsilon_{-}=0$ and $x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}=t$, b) $x_{0}-\epsilon_{-}>0$ and $x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}<t$, c) $x_{0}-\epsilon_{-}>0$ and $x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}=t$, d) $x_{0}-\epsilon_{-}=0$ and $x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}<t$. The case a) simply corresponds to the case where $\Phi$ is linear across the whole interval. The case b) implies by continuity that $a=\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}\right)=\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}\right)$ which implies that $a=0$. This cannot hold as we initially assumed that $\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}\right)<\dot{\Phi}\left(x_{0}\right)=0$ which would result in a violation of the positivity constraint. The case c) yields the contradiction $a=\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}\right)$ and $a>\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}\right)$. Finally, let us deal with case d). We prove that in this case, there exists no other point outside $\left[0, x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}\right]$such that the constraint $\alpha_{\pi} \Phi \leq \dot{\Phi}$ is not saturated ; in particular this implies that $\Phi$ is linear on $\left[0, x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}\right]$and of the form $K \exp \left(\alpha_{\pi} x\right)$ on $\left[x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}, t\right]$. Let us assume that there exists $x_{1}$ outside of $\left[0, x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}\right]$such that

$$
\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{1}\right)<\dot{\Phi}\left(x_{1}\right)
$$

Just as before, this implies the existence of $\bar{\epsilon}_{+}$such that $\Phi$ is linear across $\left[0, x_{1}+\bar{\epsilon}_{+}\right]$and such that

$$
\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{1}+\bar{\epsilon}_{+}\right) \leq \frac{\Phi\left(x_{1}+\bar{\epsilon}_{+}\right)-\Phi\left(x_{1}\right)}{\bar{\epsilon}_{+}}
$$

By linearity, if we take $\epsilon$ such that $x_{0}+\epsilon<x_{1}+\tilde{\epsilon}_{+}$, the right hand side is also given by $\frac{\Phi\left(x_{0}+\epsilon\right)-\Phi\left(x_{0}\right)}{\epsilon}$ and since $\Phi$ is strictly increasing, the left-hand side can be lower-bounded by $\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}+\epsilon\right)$ which implies

$$
\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}+\epsilon\right)<\frac{\Phi\left(x_{0}+\epsilon\right)-\Phi\left(x_{0}\right)}{\epsilon}
$$

for all $\epsilon$ such that $x_{0}+\epsilon<x_{1}+\tilde{\epsilon}_{+}$. Since $x_{1}+\tilde{\epsilon}_{+}>x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}$, this contradicts the definiton of $\epsilon_{+}$ which was chosen as the largest $\epsilon$ such that for all $\epsilon \leq \epsilon_{+}$,

$$
\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}+\epsilon\right)<\frac{\Phi\left(x_{0}+\epsilon\right)-\Phi\left(x_{0}\right)}{\epsilon}
$$

In particular, the constraint $\alpha_{\pi} \Phi \leq \dot{\Phi}$ is always saturated outside of $\left[0, x_{0}+\epsilon_{+}\right]$.
If $x_{0}=0$ As before, we obtain that $\Phi$ is either linear across the whole space $[0, t]$, either there exists $x_{0}$ such that $\Phi$ is linear across $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$ and of the form $K \exp \left(\alpha_{\pi} x\right)$ on $\left[x_{0}, t\right]$ and such that $\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}\right)=\Phi\left(x_{0}\right)$.

Summary of the minimizer candidates We can now summarize the candidates we obtained for the minimizer function $\Phi$. It has the three following possible forms:

- Form 1: $\Phi$ is an exponential function of the form $K \exp \left(\alpha_{\pi} x\right)$ on the entire interval $[0, t]$.
- Form 2: $\Phi$ is a linear function on the entire interval $[0, t]$.
- Form 3: $\Phi$ is linear function then an exponential function on the entire interval.

Specifically, there exists $x_{0} \in] 0, t[$ such that $\Phi$ is linear on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$ and of the form $K \exp \left(\alpha_{\pi} x\right)$ on $\left[x_{0}, t\right]$ and such that $\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}\right)=\dot{\Phi}\left(x_{0}\right)$.

We shall determine which candidate $\Phi$ among the three is the true minimizer, by evaluating the objective function Eq. 54 for each and picking the candidate which achieves the lowest value.

Form 1. Since $\Phi(t)=1$, it implies that the function $\Phi$ is entirely determined and given by $\Phi(x)=$ $\exp \left(\alpha_{\pi}(x-t)\right)$. In this case, the value of the objective is given by

$$
\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\Phi}^{2}(s) d s+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} \Phi(0)^{2}=\alpha_{\pi}^{2}\left[\frac{e^{2 \alpha_{\pi}(x-t)}}{2 \alpha_{\pi}}\right]_{0}^{t}+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} e^{-2 \alpha_{\pi} t},=\frac{\alpha_{\pi}}{2}+\frac{e^{-2 \alpha_{\pi} t}}{2}\left(\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}\right)
$$

Form 2. The function $\Phi$ is of the form $\Phi(x)=a x+b$. Since $\Phi(t)=1$, the coefficient $b$ is given by $1-a t$. Furthermore, the constraint $\alpha_{\pi} \Phi \leq \dot{\Phi}$ is equivalent to solving $a \geq \alpha_{\pi}$ and the constraint $\Phi \geq 0$ becomes $a \leq 1 / t$. Hence, in the case where $1 / t<\alpha_{\pi}$, there is no linear admissible potential. In the case where, $\alpha_{\pi} \leq 1 / t$, we need to solve the following one dimensional quadratic problem

$$
\inf _{1 / t \geq a \geq \alpha_{\pi}} t a^{2}+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}(1-a t)^{2}
$$

The objective can be rewritten as $\theta(a)=a^{2}\left(t+\frac{t^{2} \alpha_{\nu}}{2}\right)-a t \alpha_{\nu}+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}$. The minimum of $\theta$ is given by

$$
a_{*}:=\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2+t \alpha_{\nu}}
$$

Note that we always have $a_{*} \leq 1 / t$, hence if $\alpha_{\pi} \leq a_{*}$ the minimum is attained for $a=a_{*}$ and is given by

$$
\theta\left(a^{*}\right)=\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}-\frac{t \alpha_{\nu}^{2}}{4+2 t \alpha_{\nu}}=\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}\left(1-\frac{t \alpha_{\nu}}{2+t \alpha_{\nu}}\right)=\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2+t \alpha_{\nu}}
$$

If $\alpha_{\pi}>a_{*}$, the minimum is attained for $a=\alpha_{\pi}$ and is given by
$\theta\left(\alpha_{\pi}\right)=t \alpha_{\pi}^{2}+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}\left(1-\alpha_{\pi} t\right)^{2}=t \alpha_{\pi}^{2}+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}-\alpha_{\nu} \alpha_{\pi} t+\left(t \alpha_{\pi}\right)^{2} \frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}=t \alpha_{\pi}\left(\alpha_{\pi}-\alpha_{\nu}+t \frac{\alpha_{\pi} \alpha_{\nu}}{2}\right)+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}$.

Form 3. There exists $0<x_{0}<t$ such that the function $\Phi$ is of the form $a x+b$ over $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$ and then is given by $e^{\alpha_{\pi}(x-t)}$ over $\left[x_{0}, t\right]$ and which is such that $\Phi\left(x_{0}\right)=\alpha_{\pi} \Phi\left(x_{0}\right)$. The continuity of $\Phi$ implies that $a x_{0}+b=e^{\alpha_{\pi}\left(x_{0}-t\right)}$ and the previous equation gives $a=\left(a x_{0}+b\right) \alpha_{\pi}$. Both these equations uniquely determine $a$ and $b$ when $x_{0}$ is fixed as

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
a & =\alpha_{\pi} e^{\alpha_{\pi}\left(x_{0}-t\right)} \\
b & =e^{\alpha_{\pi}\left(x_{0}-t\right)}\left(1-\alpha_{\pi} x_{0}\right)
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

and in particular the positivity constraint is equivalent to $x_{0} \leq \frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}$; note that the constraint $\alpha_{\pi} \Phi \leq \hat{\Phi}$ is indeed respected over $[0, t]$. Hence, we must solve the following one dimensional problem

$$
\inf _{0 \leq x_{0} \leq \min \left(t, \frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}\right)} x_{0} \alpha_{\pi}^{2} e^{2 \alpha_{\pi}\left(x_{0}-t\right)}+\frac{\alpha_{\pi}}{2}\left(1-e^{2 \alpha_{\pi}\left(x_{0}-t\right)}\right)+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2} e^{2 \alpha_{\pi}\left(x_{0}-t\right)}\left(1-\alpha_{\pi} x_{0}\right)^{2}
$$

Let us remark that $x_{0}=0$ being an admissible candidate, the potential $\Phi(x)=e^{\alpha_{\pi}(x-t)}$ is indeed an admissible candidate and in particular, the value of the problem above is always lower than the one obtained with Form 1. Denoting $f$ the objective function, let us compute the derivative of $f$. For all $x_{0}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)= & \alpha_{\pi}^{2} e^{2\left(x_{0}-t\right)}+2 x_{0} \alpha_{\pi}^{3} e^{2\left(x_{0}-t\right)}-\alpha_{\pi}^{2} e^{2\left(x_{0}-t\right)}+\alpha_{\pi} \alpha_{\nu}\left(1-x_{0} \alpha_{\pi}\right)^{2} e^{2\left(x_{0}-t\right)} \\
& -\alpha_{\nu} \alpha_{\pi}\left(1-x_{0} \alpha_{\pi}\right) e^{2\left(x_{0}-t\right)} \\
= & e^{2\left(x_{0}-t\right)} \alpha_{\pi}\left(2 x_{0} \alpha_{\pi}^{2}-\alpha_{\nu}\left(1-x_{0} \alpha_{\pi}\right)\left(1-1+x_{0} \alpha_{\pi}\right)\right) \\
= & x_{0} e^{2\left(x_{0}-t\right)} \alpha_{\pi}^{2}\left(2 \alpha_{\pi}-\alpha_{\nu}\left(1-x_{0} \alpha_{\pi}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The term $\left(2 \alpha_{\pi}-\alpha_{\nu}\left(1-x_{0} \alpha_{\pi}\right)\right)$ cancels for $x_{0}=\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}$, hence if $\alpha_{\pi} \geq \frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}$, the derivative $f^{\prime}$ is always non-negative for all $x_{0} \geq 0$ hence the optimal choice of $x_{0}$ is given by $x_{0}=0$. Let us remark that this case implies $\alpha_{\pi}>a_{*}$ where $a_{*}$ is defined in Eq. 56 and for which the optimal Form 2. is given by $\Phi(x)=\alpha_{\pi} x+\left(1-t \alpha_{\pi}\right)$ which an admissible candidate for Form 3. This proves that whenever $\alpha_{\pi}>\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}$, the optimal potential is given by $\Phi(x)=e^{\alpha_{\pi}(s-t)}$.with $x_{0}=t$. If $\alpha_{\pi}<\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}$, then $f$ decreases between 0 and $\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}$ and then increases. In particular, since $\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}<\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}$, the minimum is attained for $x_{0}=\min \left(t, \frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}\right)$. In the case where $t \leq \frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}$ which is equivalent to $\alpha_{\pi} \leq a_{*}$ with $a_{*}$ defined in Eq. 56 , the obtained potential is linear hence it is necessarily sub-optimal with respect to Form 2. which yields as an optimal potential

$$
\Phi(x)=a_{*} x+\left(1-a_{*} t\right)
$$

Let us now place ourselves in the case $t>\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}$. In the case where $t>\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}$, which is equivalent to $\alpha_{\pi}>a_{*}$, the optimal potential yielded by Form 2. (if any) is given by $\Phi(x)=\alpha_{\pi} x+\left(1-\alpha_{\pi} t\right)$ which is admissible for Form 3. by taking $x_{0}=t$ hence, Form 3. is necessarily sub-optimal.

As a conclusion, we have obtained the following expressions for $\Phi$ :

1. If $\alpha_{\pi}>\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}$, we have $\Phi(x)=e^{\alpha_{\pi}(x-t)}$.
2. If $\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{t \alpha_{\nu}+2}<\alpha_{\pi} \leq \frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}$, then $\Phi$ is given by

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{c}
\Phi(x)=\alpha_{\pi} e^{\alpha_{\pi}\left(\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}-t\right)} x+\frac{2 \alpha_{\pi}}{\alpha_{\nu}} e^{\alpha_{\pi}\left(\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}-t\right)} \text { if } x \leq \frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}} \\
\Phi(x)=e^{\alpha_{\pi}(x-t)} \text { if } x>\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{2}{\alpha_{\nu}}
\end{array}\right.
$$

3. If $\alpha_{\pi} \leq \frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{t \alpha_{\nu}+2}$, then $\Phi(x)=\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2+t \alpha_{\nu}} x+\left(1-\frac{t \alpha_{\nu}}{2+t \alpha_{\nu}}\right)$.

Note that in any case, $\Phi$ is in fact continuously differentiable and verifies almost everywhere $\bar{\Phi} \Phi \leq$ $\bar{\Phi}^{2}$ as well as $\bar{\Phi} \leq \alpha_{\nu} \Phi$, hence it is a solution of the problem

$$
\inf _{\Phi \geq 0, \bar{\Phi} \Phi \leq \bar{\Phi}^{2}} \int_{0}^{\bar{\Phi}^{2}(s) d s+\frac{\alpha_{\nu}}{2}} \Phi(0)^{2}
$$

$\Phi(t)=1, \alpha_{*} \Phi \leq \bar{\Phi} \leq \alpha_{\nu} \Phi$.

The optimal $\Phi$ is linked to the optimal tempering scheme $\lambda$ as $\lambda_{s}=\frac{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}$ with $\alpha_{s}=\partial_{s} \log (\Phi)$. Hence we obtain

$$
\lambda_{s}=\min \left(1, \frac{\alpha_{\nu}\left(\alpha_{\nu} s+1\right)}{\left(\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}\right)\left(\alpha_{\nu} s+2\right)}\right)
$$

# C. 3 Proof of Proposition 7 

Reversing the integration by parts we have

$$
G_{t}(\lambda)=1-2 \int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \alpha_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{\nu} \mathrm{d} v\right) \mathrm{d} s=\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\lambda}_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{\nu} \mathrm{d} v\right) \mathrm{d} s
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
G_{t}(\lambda) & =\int_{0}^{t} \dot{\lambda}_{s} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t} \alpha_{\nu} d v\right) d s \\
& =\frac{1}{t} \int_{0}^{t} \exp \left(-2 \int_{s}^{t}\left(\frac{v}{t}\left(\alpha_{\pi}-\alpha_{\nu}\right)+\alpha_{\nu}\right) d v\right) d s \\
& =\frac{1}{t} \int_{0}^{t} \exp \left(-2 \frac{\alpha_{\pi}-\alpha_{\nu}}{t} \frac{1}{2}\left(t^{2}-s^{2}\right)-2(t-s) \alpha_{\nu}\right) d s \\
& =\frac{1}{t} \int_{0}^{t} \exp \left(-\frac{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}{t} s^{2}+2 \alpha_{\nu} s-t\left(\alpha_{\nu}+\alpha_{\pi}\right)\right) d s
\end{aligned}
$$

Recall that for generic $a, b, c>0$, we have

$$
\int \exp \left(-a x^{2}+b x-c\right) d x=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2 \sqrt{a}} \exp \left(b^{2} / 4 a-c\right) \operatorname{erf}((2 a x-b) /(2 \sqrt{a}))+\text { constant }
$$

We may apply this formula since $\alpha_{\pi}<\alpha_{\nu}$. it yields the equality claim:

$$
G_{t}(\lambda)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{t}} \frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2 \sqrt{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}} \exp \left(\frac{t \alpha_{\pi}^{2}}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\right)\left(\operatorname{erf}\left(\frac{\sqrt{t} \alpha_{\nu}}{\sqrt{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}}\right)-\operatorname{erf}\left(\frac{\sqrt{t} \alpha_{\pi}}{\sqrt{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}}\right)\right)
$$

Now, let us consider the behavior of $G_{t}(\lambda)$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$. Here, we Taylor expand to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{erf}\left(\frac{\sqrt{t} \alpha_{\nu}}{\sqrt{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}}\right)-\operatorname{erf}\left(\frac{\sqrt{t} \alpha_{\pi}}{\sqrt{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}}\right) \\
& =\sqrt{\frac{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}{t \pi}}\left(\frac{1}{\alpha_{\pi}} \exp \left(-\frac{t \alpha_{\pi}^{2}}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\right)-\frac{1}{\alpha_{\nu}} \exp \left(-\frac{t \alpha_{\nu}^{2}}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\right)\right) \\
& +O\left(\frac{1}{t^{3 / 2}}\right)\left(\exp \left(-\frac{t \alpha_{\nu}^{2}}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\right)-\exp \left(-\frac{t \alpha_{\pi}^{2}}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore

$$
G_{t}(\lambda)=\frac{1}{2 t \alpha_{\pi}}-\frac{1}{2 t \alpha_{\nu}} \exp \left(\frac{-t \alpha_{\nu}^{2}-\alpha_{\pi}^{2}}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\right)+O\left(\frac{1}{t} \exp \left(\frac{-t \alpha_{\nu}^{2}-\alpha_{\pi}^{2}}{\alpha_{\nu}-\alpha_{\pi}}\right)\right)
$$

This yields the claimed asymptotic result.
These results are numerically validated in Figure 3.

## D LOWER BOUNDS

In this section, we give the proofs of Theorems 4, 8 and 9. In section D. 1 we prove a general lower bound in total variation for the setup we consider in Theorems 8 and 9. We apply this result to the bimodal example in section D.2. We then study the unimodal examples from Theorems 4 and 9 in section D.3. The bound on the log-Sobolev constant for the uni-modal example is deferred to section D.4. Throughout, we use the notation introduced in section 5.

Dashed lines are our prediction from Proposition 7 and full lines are from simulations of the process using 10000 particles.
